metadata.title: From the frontlines of COVID‐19 – How prepared are we as obstetricians: a commentary
metadata.author: Monica Shi Qi Chua, Jill Cheng Sim Lee, Suzanna Sulaiman, Hak Koon Tan

metadata.journal: BJOG: An International Journal of Obstetrics & Gynaecology
metadata.abstract: The World Health Organization (WHO) has declared the outbreak of novel coronavirus (2019-nCoV) – now known as Coronavirus Disease (COVID-19)1 - as a global health emergency. Singapore currently stands as the country with the highest number of reported cases of COVID-19 outside of China[2], excluding patients on a cruise ship offshore of Japan. It has been a week since the Ministry of Health of Singapore declared an increased alert level using its Disease Outbreak Response System Condition (DORSCON) framework to DORSCON Orange. This indicates that COVID-19 is considered a severe disease which spreads easily from person to person, but has not spread widely in Singapore and is presently being contained. This escalation in framework results in

ethical_compliance: Details of ethics approval No ethics approval applicable for this commentary
introduction: 1. Travel to or residence within the last 14 days in China 2. History of contact with a healthcare facility in China or
- History of close contact with a confirmed case of COVID-19 within 14 days before onset of illness or

participants.context: LABOUR AND DELIVERY A recent study conducted by Chen et al[9] showed no evidence of intrauterine infection of COVID-19 caused by vertical transmission from mothers who developed COVID-19 pneumonia in their third trimesters. However, all nine cases studied were delivered via caesarean section and they were unable to analyze if COVID-19 could be transmitted via vaginal delivery since no vaginal mucosa samples were taken. Previous studies have shown the possibility of materno-fetal transmission of human coronavirus (HCoV)[10] with evidence of the virus not only in maternal respiratory swabs, but also in vaginal swabs

summary: - History of close contact with a confirmed case of COVID-19 within 14 days before onset of illness or

- Staff who are caring for suspected or confirmed cases of COVID-19 patients should be closely monitored for fever or other signs of infection and should not be working in the presence of any COVID-19 symptoms.

LABOUR AND DELIVERY A recent study conducted by Chen et al[9] showed no evidence of intrauterine infection of COVID-19 caused by vertical transmission from mothers who developed COVID-19 pneumonia in their third trimesters.
Postpartum Recommendations - Infected or suspect mothers should refrain from breastfeeding until she has fully recovered or has been confirmed not to have COVID-19.
- Mothers and newborns are to be isolated separately to prevent neonatal transmission until she has fully recovered or confirmed not to have COVID-19.
The potential need to separate mothers with or suspected to have COVID-19 from their newborns, and being unable to breastfeed, may impede early bonding as well as establishment of lactation.
In addition to caring for their physical wellbeing, medical teams should pay more attention to the mental wellness of these mothers, providing the appropriate concern and support when needed.

REFLECTIONS OF FRONTLINE OBSTETRICIANS In response to the COVID-19 outbreak, the Division of Obstetrics and Gynaecology at KKH have established isolation (ISO) teams consisting of dedicated teams of doctors and nurses assigned to care for patients who fit the criteria for isolation at screening.

As doctors assigned to this team, the authors ourselves are “isolated” during the daily 12-hourly shifts to minimize contact with other patients and colleagues, with an aim to reduce the risk of exposure and potential transmission.

As the authors aim to restrict movements to minimize contact and transmission, doctors in isolation become reliant on others – from practical things like food and drinks for sustenance, to topping up of PPE and medical equipment in the isolation rooms.
As the knowledge of COVID-19 increases, hospital recommendations on infection control, COVID-19 screening and isolation change rapidly in accordance with the latest evidence.

From being informed that the authors will be part of the first ISO team just a couple of hours after the declaration of DORSCON Orange in Singapore, the feelings of anxiety and stress as the authors face many uncertainties, to the growing fear that with rising number of cases of COVID-19, each patient the authors see adds greater risk to the personal health and that of the people around us.

Introduction: - History of close contact with a confirmed case of COVID-19 within 14 days before onset of illness or

- Staff who are caring for suspected or confirmed cases of COVID-19 patients should be closely monitored for fever or other signs of infection and should not be working in the presence of any COVID-19 symptoms.

LABOUR AND DELIVERY A recent study conducted by Chen et al[9] showed no evidence of intrauterine infection of COVID-19 caused by vertical transmission from mothers who developed COVID-19 pneumonia in their third trimesters.
Results: Postpartum Recommendations - Infected or suspect mothers should refrain from breastfeeding until she has fully recovered or has been confirmed not to have COVID-19.
- Mothers and newborns are to be isolated separately to prevent neonatal transmission until she has fully recovered or confirmed not to have COVID-19.
The potential need to separate mothers with or suspected to have COVID-19 from their newborns, and being unable to breastfeed, may impede early bonding as well as establishment of lactation.
In addition to caring for their physical wellbeing, medical teams should pay more attention to the mental wellness of these mothers, providing the appropriate concern and support when needed.

REFLECTIONS OF FRONTLINE OBSTETRICIANS In response to the COVID-19 outbreak, the Division of Obstetrics and Gynaecology at KKH have established isolation (ISO) teams consisting of dedicated teams of doctors and nurses assigned to care for patients who fit the criteria for isolation at screening.

As doctors assigned to this team, the authors ourselves are “isolated” during the daily 12-hourly shifts to minimize contact with other patients and colleagues, with an aim to reduce the risk of exposure and potential transmission.

As the authors aim to restrict movements to minimize contact and transmission, doctors in isolation become reliant on others – from practical things like food and drinks for sustenance, to topping up of PPE and medical equipment in the isolation rooms.
Conclusion: As the knowledge of COVID-19 increases, hospital recommendations on infection control, COVID-19 screening and isolation change rapidly in accordance with the latest evidence.

From being informed that the authors will be part of the first ISO team just a couple of hours after the declaration of DORSCON Orange in Singapore, the feelings of anxiety and stress as the authors face many uncertainties, to the growing fear that with rising number of cases of COVID-19, each patient the authors see adds greater risk to the personal health and that of the people around us.

claims: Results from this study revealed changes in placentas that are most likely related to disruption in the maternal placental blood flow during hypoxic episodes of the acute stages of their illness
key_statements: - Negative pressure isolation rooms should be set up for safe labour and delivery. - Isolated patients should only be cared for by a dedicated team of doctors and nurses who only care for patients meeting these strict triaging criteria, and should not care for other low-risk patients. - Staff who are caring for suspected or confirmed cases of COVID-19 patients should be closely monitored for fever or other signs of infection and should not be working in the presence of any COVID-19 symptoms

LABOUR AND DELIVERY A recent study conducted by Chen et al[9] showed no evidence of intrauterine infection of COVID-19 caused by vertical transmission from mothers who developed COVID-19 pneumonia in their third trimesters

As we aim to restrict movements to minimize contact and transmission, doctors in isolation become reliant on others – from practical things like food and drinks for sustenance, to topping up of protective equipment and medical equipment in the isolation rooms
